data.ner:
Consider the function,
$$
F(x)=(x-1)^{2}+1
$$
The objective is to find the derivative of the function by using the definition, and then find the
value of the derivative at $F^{\prime}(-1), F^{\prime}(0),$ and $F^{\prime}(2)$

The derivative of the function, $f(x),$ with respect to the variable $x,$ is the function $f^{\prime}(x)$
whose value at $x$ is,
$$
\begin{aligned}
F^{\prime}(x) &=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{F(x+h)-F(x)}{h} \\
&=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left[(x+h-1)^{2}+1\right]-\left[(x-1)^{2}+1\right]}{h} \\
&=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{(x-1)^{2}+h^{2}+2 h(x-1)+1-(x-1)^{2}-1}{h} \\
&=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{h^{2}+2 h(x-1)}{h} \\
&=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0}[h+2(x-1)] \\
&=2(x-1)
\end{aligned}
$$
Therefore, the derivative of the function $F(x)=(x-1)^{2}+1$ is $F^{\prime}(x)=2(x-1)$

Find the values of $F^{\prime}$ at $x=-1,0,2$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { At } x=-1 \\
\begin{aligned}
F^{\prime}(-1) &=2(-1-1) \\
&=-4 \\
\text { At } x=0 & \\
F^{\prime}(0) &=2(0-1) \\
&=-2 \\
\text { At } x=& 2 \\
F^{\prime}(2) &=2(2-1) \\
&=2
\end{aligned}
\end{array}
$$
